The bodhisattva thus deeply enters the Dharma realm and teaches sentient beings, yet has no attachment to sentient beings;
He upholds all dharmas, yet has no attachment to any dharmas;
He gives rise to the bodhi mind and abides in the Buddha's abode, yet has no attachment to the Buddha's abode;

They abandon the level path and enter into dangerous paths;
They forsake the Buddha's intention and follow the intentions of demons;
They firmly cling to existence and do not let go.
' The bodhisattva observes sentient beings in this way, and his great compassion grows. He generates roots of goodness without attachment.
At that time, the bodhisattva further thinks like this:
'I should, for a single sentient being, in each country of the worlds in the ten directions, for unspeakable eons, teach and transform them to maturity.
As I do for a single sentient being, so I do for all sentient beings;
I will never become weary of this, abandon it, and leave.'
Moreover, using the tip of a hair to measure the Dharma realm, in each tip of a hair, for unspeakable, unspeakable eons, they teach and transform all sentient beings;
Just as in each tip of a hair, in each and every tip of a hair, it is also like this.
Up to not, for the duration of a finger snap, grasping onto a self, giving rise to thoughts of self and what belongs to self.
In each and every tip of a hair, for future eons, they cultivate bodhisattva practices;

He also thought like this:

'I should practice the bodhisattva path in the lands of the ten directions throughout the entire Dharma realm of space, clearly understanding all Buddha Dharmas in every thought, with right mindfulness present, without attachment.'

The bodhisattva, observing the body as selfless in this way, sees the Buddha without obstruction, and in order to transform sentient beings, expounds the Dharmas, causing them to generate immeasurable joy and pure faith in the Buddha Dharma, to save and protect all, with an untiring mind.
Because of being untiring, in all worlds, wherever there are sentient beings who have not yet matured or been tamed, he goes there all and skillfully transforms and delivers them.

The various sounds, various karmas, various attachments, various designations, various combinations, various transmigrations, various activities, various objects, various births, and various deaths of the sentient beings therein, with great vows, abide within them and teach them, not allowing their minds to move or regress, and also not giving rise to a single thought of attachment.
Why is this?
